Infections of rabies increase in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Tawichai of the 9th Disease Prevention and Management Office revealed on February 9 that rabies infections have been on the rise in northeastern Thailand over the past few months, with a total of 74 infected people.

As of the beginning of this fiscal year (October last year to September this year), a total of 74 people have been confirmed to have rabies in the northeastern provinces of Surin and Buri Ram, with 67 in Surin and seven in Buri Ram.
It is said that all of them have been vaccinated against rabies in the past.
The doctor is calling on people to get vaccinated against rabies along with their pets, and to avoid touching the saliva of animals suspected of being infected.
Rabies can be contracted not only from dogs but also from cats and bats.
If a person is infected and develops the disease, they will almost certainly die, but if they are vaccinated before they develop the disease, they can be saved.

FUJI 置き去り事故防止へ システム開発自社車両で実験|中部経済新聞 愛知・岐阜・三重・静岡の経済情報

FUJI (headquarters in Chiryu City), which manufactures and sells electronic parts and robots and work machines, has taken on the development of a system to prevent "abandonment" such as leaving children in cars.
A system that attaches a human sensor to the inside of a car and sends a notification to a phone or chat when it detects movement.
Currently, we are conducting a test experiment using our own company's shuttle vehicles.
In the midst of accidents caused by being left behind, we will protect the safety of children.

Currently, the company is conducting a trial experiment using two vehicles that are used to transport children to and from the company's own English conversation after school program "teracoya THANK (テラコヤ サンク)" in Chiryu City.
Motion sensors that detect human movement based on the temperature difference between the human body and the surrounding environment are installed in three locations on the ceiling of the vehicle.

When it detects no human presence for a given amount of time, it automatically shuts off. When the engine is turned off and the doors are closed, if it detects movement after a certain amount of time has passed, it automatically sends a warning notification.
By linking the engine and door status and information, it is possible to prevent false detection as much as possible.
The notification of the warning is sent through the cloud.
You can either call a number that you have registered in advance, or display it on your computer or smartphone chat.
It is possible to register at multiple addresses, and it is designed to prevent oversight and other mistakes.
The demonstration experiment will continue until the end of February.
Kanatani Isoroku, chief of the 2nd section of the Innovation Promotion Department, pointed out, "During the experiment, we've noticed peripheral issues that are not related to the system."
For example, it has been possible to pick up a variety of issues related to school buses, such as creating an environment in which drivers can concentrate on driving.
He said, "I want to spread the solution as much as possible."
The development of the "placement prevention system" was triggered by a series of incidents in which school buses were left unattended across the country.
A member with children asked if there was anything that could be done to protect the safety of children.
Through FA (Factory Automation) related business, he developed the know-how of IoT (Internet of Things) and information management using sensors, and decided to develop it.
FUJI's removal prevention system is sold on its ease of use.
The sensor can be installed by simply pinning it to the ceiling.
Because it can be easily attached to delivery vehicles, it reduces the hurdles to implementation and aims to popularize it.
In the future, we will also consider productization while seeking cooperation from nurseries and kindergartens.

The cat-shaped robot that is used for food delivery at the "Iwasa Aged Jingisukan Bon Fukui Station Front Store".
Fukui Prefecture Fukui City Otsu 2-cho: Family customers love the cute expressions =
In the food service industry in Fukui Prefecture, which is plagued by a shortage of workers, the trend of introducing robots that deliver food to tables is spreading.

It is said that the robot's cute expressions have been well received by families, and it is expected to help with labor-saving in store operations and "non-contact" customer service to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
A voice from restaurant owners and related parties says, "It's difficult for local restaurants to secure employees and part-timers, so I think that delivery robots will become even more popular."
It is a rainy night in Georgia - do you remember that song?
A robot with a cat's face on the screen, playing light music, glides smoothly through the restaurant with a tray of food.
When it arrives at the table, it says, "I've brought your order, meow."
In August 2022, "Iwashima Yakumono Jingisukan Bon Fukui Station Front Store" in 2-cho, Otsu, Fukui City, introduced a cat-shaped food delivery robot.
When a customer places an order, the robot, which is waiting nearby the kitchen, will load the food onto its tray and autonomously walk to the table with the number displayed on the screen.
It is equipped with AI (artificial intelligence) voice function, and reacts when touched by customers, and the expression of the cat face on the screen is also rich.
The group that runs this restaurant, "BonTa Group," has introduced the delivery robots at two restaurants, including this one.

Saito Toshinobu, president of Bonta Group, said the reason for the introduction was "the biggest problem is a shortage of workers," and emphasized that it is part of efforts to improve productivity through automation and digital transformation (DX).
The ratio of labor costs to sales at the store is usually around 30%, but it has been reduced to 21-22% by the introduction of the robot.

The robots also have the role of collecting dishes that have been eaten by customers, which contributes to the efficiency of cleaning up, and adds, "It is also a good thing for families and children to enjoy, and it has a promotional effect."
The "Rokkan Yama Fukui" restaurant, which serves grilled meat and hot pot, located in Araki Shinpo-cho, Fukui City, also introduced a food delivery robot in August 2022.

Star Mountain Yufuku, the president of the Sonzan store, said, "We have been having a hard time recruiting employees and part-timers. I thought it was absolutely necessary to solve the personnel shortage."
At the Fukui store, the area where employees serve food and the area where the robot delivers food are separated.
The rental fee for the robot is said to be the same as the wage of one part-time worker.
In order to reduce the number of employees, the restaurant is also considering the introduction of a tablet ordering system and self-service kiosks.

According to the Fukui Labor Bureau, the effective demand ratio for job categories in December 2022 was 6.94 times for "customer service" jobs in restaurants, etc., and is a job category with a high shortage of workers.

The person in charge of the network system that sells robot waiters (Kamiguchi Naka-chome 2-cho, Fukui City) said, "The shortage of staff in restaurants in the prefecture has become more serious due to the impact of the coronavirus, and there has been a lot of inquiries about robot introduction."
President Hoshiyama commented, "I think that it will become even more difficult to secure employees at suburban restaurants in the future, and that delivery robots will become more widespread."

Last year, they published a "inheritance handbook" that includes necessary procedures and forms for when a family member dies, such as a list of assets and a family tree, and many people came to receive it for themselves.

In various parts of the prefecture, lectures on how to write an ending note and how to organize one's belongings before death are being held, and it seems that "shuukatsu" has become firmly rooted in the minds of the prefectural residents.
The ending note of Echizen Town is 35 pages.

It is divided into five chapters, starting with a review of one's life, and records one's current health and assets, wishes for future care and end-of-life medical care, and wishes for funerals and graves.
There is also a column for things you want to do in your remaining life and a column for leaving a message for your loved ones.
Although it is said to be 35 pages, it is not necessary to fill out all the pages.
What do you want to leave behind for your family and the people around you?
The important thing is to make the purpose clear.
You can start writing from the place where you can write, and there are various notebooks for sale at bookstores that are suitable for the purpose.
The term "terminal employment" was coined in 2009, when the job market was particularly tough.
Two years later, in 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
Many people were confronted with the reality that "death comes suddenly," and it is said that the number of people who prepare for their own end and final stages of life has increased.
It's been more than 10 years since then.
The coronavirus pandemic that swept the world has not yet subsided.
The invasion of Ukraine by Russia and soaring prices have caused the price of electricity this winter to skyrocket to an unthinkable level.
On the other hand, wages have not risen to match the current high prices, causing many people to worry about the future.
On the other hand, funeral expenses and care expenses that were once shared by relatives are now rare in the age of only children.
Also, compared to a few years ago, life expectancy has increased, but the risk of dementia and nursing care increases as you get older.
I want to keep in mind that the background of the end of life is not just the end of life itself, but also the rise of social anxiety.
After all, who wouldn't want to avoid burdening their partner or children too much?
"Ending Note" is a popular keyword, but it is not good to be too lonely.
I don't want to keep my wishes and requests to myself, but I want to talk to my family once and prepare for it calmly.

At the graduation ceremony, it is not necessary to wear masks for children and teachers in principle = February 10, Saitama Prefecture, Toda City
On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that it is the basic policy that children and students do not wear masks at graduation ceremonies.

The headmaster of a large junior high school said, "It's actually difficult to keep a wide distance between students, and I'm wondering how to deal with it. There are also students who feel uneasy about taking off their masks."
According to reports on the wearing of masks at graduation ceremonies, the topic has also been raised among teachers.
On the other hand, a principal of a primary school said, "If the government decides, it will be a form where they don't wear masks. If it's not a choir, it's not practically possible."

At this graduation ceremony, there are also moves to ease the countermeasures at some schools in the prefecture, such as allowing the participation of students who were absent from school and restarting the graduation choir.

In the prefecture, the prefectural high school is scheduled to hold the ceremony in early March, and the public elementary and junior high schools are scheduled to hold the ceremony in the middle of the month.

The prefectural and municipal education committees are waiting for the official notification from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology to make a decision on how to respond.
In addition, there are cautious voices regarding the Ministry of Education's decision to not require the use of masks in all school activities starting this spring.

A primary school principal said, "Suddenly telling children to not wear masks will confuse them. If we decide to let them wear masks freely, it's natural that more children will take them off and play with them."

On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that from April, it will not require the wearing of masks in school education activities, in line with the new government guidelines on mask wearing.
Masks will be optional in choir, physical education classes, and club activities.

For the current academic year, the ministry will continue to request infection prevention measures in accordance with the current hygiene management manual, and will inform the education committee and school sites of the points to be aware of after April.

Graduation ceremonies at elementary, junior high, and high schools, as well as universities, will continue to be held with ventilation and other measures in place, and graduates, teachers, and students who attend will be required to wear masks as a general rule.

NPO organization "Kokoro ni Kagayaku Shuinshu / Editing Bureau" self-published the book "Dear Prime Minister, the "Breakwater of Life" from Tōjinbō"
This is the 10th book we have published under the title "Dear Prime Minister, 'Breakwater of Life' from Tōjinbō".
It has been picked up by newspapers all over the country, and we have received many letters of thanks from readers.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share with everyone the contents of the "social and structural" environmental problems that I have heard directly from those who have attempted suicide in Japan, and to create a "society where people can live comfortably".

We have been patrolling the water's edge of Tōjinbō in Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months, in order to prevent suicide, and have been continuing to support the activities of discovering and protecting those who are planning to commit suicide, and helping them to start again.

This book is a compilation of the problems that have been heard from 784 people (2/6 currently) who have been protected so far, and as a request to the Prime Minister of the Cabinet, it calls for the following seven items to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, there are "human rights violations" piling up.
(3)Suicides are victims of organized crime in the social and structural sense.
(4) Administrative agencies treat citizens who live outside their jurisdiction as "strangers" and neglect them.
(5) Mental illness patients such as depression are drugged and treated as accidents even if they commit suicide.
(6) In the high-risk areas of suicide, the "duty of care" is forgotten and commercialism is running rampant.

(7) The teachings of new religious organizations that cannot be scientifically proven are deceptive and the act of threatening to curse them in the future and offering them gold in exchange for money is blackmail.
It is necessary to publicly denounce and exclude the religious organizations that commit the crime of "fraud and extortion".

So, we have received a lot of feedback from readers of this book, and we have been moved by the strong mentalities of those who are involved in this activity, and we have been impressed by the fact that this former police officer is a bodhisattva who supports others as if they were his own family, and we have been moved by the fact that this former police officer is a bodhisattva who supports others as if they were his own family, and we have been moved by
I was moved to tears when I saw the photo in the newspaper article and thought, "What are you thinking...".
I hear that the number of suicides among people who have been pushed to the wall by the pandemic is increasing.
It is a VERY SAD "life" really.
Everyone is like that.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can live happily with the lives we have received.
I felt respect and gratitude for the staff who have been working tirelessly to help people who are suffering so much that they feel like they want to die.
I think this activity is mentally and physically exhausting, but please continue to support us with your kind words.
Thank you very much.
So bring on the horror, the fear and alarm.
I hope that all of you readers will become gatekeepers of life in your regions.

Toba City to double child-rearing allowance payments, seeks repayment - Ise Newspaper
【鳥羽】鳥羽市は10日、令和3年度の子育て世帯生活支援特別給付金(その他世帯分)について、11世帯12人に合計60万円の誤支給があったと発表した。
The City said it is seeking compensation for the overpayment.
According to the city, the error was discovered on January 27, 2021, when the guardian of a child who had received the payment in the past pointed out the error.
It was confirmed that out of 79 households and 182 people who were the recipients of the allowance for that year, 11 households and 12 people received the allowance twice on July 20, 2020.
The city pays 50,000 yen per child to households with children up to high school age who are not subject to resident tax.

The city had received data on the children who were the target of the subsidy from a computer company that was commissioned to extract the data, but a staff member mistakenly added high school students to the data, thinking that they were not included, and as a result, the subsidy was paid twice.
The person in charge of the city's childcare support room said, "We will take this situation seriously and make every effort to prevent a recurrence, such as rechecking the data."

On the 10th, the prefecture and Ichinoseki city announced that the Bellino Hotel Ichinoseki (Yamagawa, Ichinoseki city) had been receiving inappropriate subsidies for the accommodation support program, which deducts the cost of accommodation from travelers, for about a year since October 2021.
When people who were not eligible for the discount stayed, employees would apply the discount by giving them a false name.
It was confirmed that a large number of cases of lodging use by employees that did not follow the purpose of the event, "stimulating the need for tourism."

Including the self-investigation of the prefecture and the city, as well as the inappropriate use, the total amount of the subsidy received was 7,231,000 yen, which was returned by the 6th of this month.

The improper receipt of subsidies was found in the prefectural lodging discount "Iwate Travel Support Project," which was implemented due to the spread of the new coronavirus infection, and the city's emergency measures for tourism lodging facilities "Ichinoseki Lodging Support Discount."

The period was from October 18, 2021 to October 10, 2022 (September 30, 2022 for the "Ichinoseki Accommodation Support Cut"), and as a result of the investigation, inappropriate use that did not qualify for the discount, such as staying outside the target area or not being vaccinated, amounted to 95 cases, 587,000 yen, and inappropriate use that did not follow the purpose and goals of the project amounted

The county's business delegation was in charge of the accounting process, and it was confirmed that the same person was both the user of the lodging discount and the person in charge of accepting it from the hotel side on multiple occasions.

Introducing the forefather of plant research, and the collection of Mount Hayachine, at the city's comprehensive cultural property center exhibition [Hanamaki] | Iwanichi Online Iwate Nippo Newspaper Co., Ltd.

The exhibition "People who introduced the flowers of Hayachine Peak - A brief history of the study of plants in Hayachine Peak" that introduces the pioneers who laid the foundation for the study of plants in Hayachine Peak, which is known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, is being held at the city's comprehensive cultural property center in Ohasama, Hanamaki, until the 12th.
The exhibition introduces the footprints of the pioneers who collected precious specimens and other materials.

The study of plants on Mount Hayachine began with the arrival of Russian botanist Karl Ivanovich Maximowicz (1827-91) in the late Edo period, and with the collection of plants under Maximowicz's guidance by Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), who was born in Shibawacho.
Maximowitch, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country for foreigners, asked Sukawa to collect plants, and continued his research for three years with Yokohama and Nagasaki as his base.

After Makino returned to Russia, Tsukawa continued to support his research, and this led to the publication of the "Himekazura", "Nambotouwachisou", and "Miyamayamabukishouma", which are unique to Mount Hayachine.

After that, the modern plant taxonomist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cerastium kawakamii", "Draba japonica", and "Arenaria katoana", which he discovered and named himself on Mount Asadake in 1903 (Meiji 36) and 1905 (Meiji 38), based on the specimens collected by local researchers.<
From the exhibition materials, it is clear that many researchers have revealed precious alpine plants.

Also introduced are Shinozaki Masaoki (1874-1948), the principal of Hanaokamochi Elementary School who conducted plant research while accompanying the survey for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamakawa Nanjiro (1914-1988), a teacher at the Tamakawa Mountain Museum who also contributed to the publication of "Plants of Takadaira Peak".

Yoshida Junpei, a researcher at the center, said, "Each plant on Mount Hayachine has a background of many studies and connections with people. It can be a bridge connecting researchers from all over the country who come from local areas."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters, and in the first chapter, the faith and history of Mount Hayachine is introduced, and in the second chapter, the exhibition focuses on the characteristics of Mount Hayachine from a geological perspective, based on the research of German geologist Heinrich Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), who laid the foundation of Japanese geology.

Discussing the introduction of renewable energy and goals at Amami Airport, the second decarbonization promotion council|Society and Economy |Nansei Nippo
Discussion on decarbonization of Amami Airport = On the 9th, in Kasaricho, Amami

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Anbe Shun, Chief of the Construction Section of the Oshima Subprefectural Office, 13 members) which is composed of prefectural governments and airlines that use Amami Airport (Shirayama-cho, Amami City) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All committee members, including online, attended.
The meeting discussed the setting of decarbonization goals and exchanged opinions on the introduction of renewable energy, with solar power generation as the main source.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 46% or more by 2030 (compared to 2013) in order to achieve "carbon neutrality" by 2050, and each airport has set a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
In response to this, the council held its first meeting in November of last year, and is aiming to plan ahead of the other six airports in the prefecture.
The second meeting was held in a non-public manner, just like the first meeting, except for the opening.
After the meeting, Chairman Ando responded to inquiries by saying that the meeting confirmed the greenhouse gas emissions of the airport.
The meeting was held to discuss the setting of goals and the introduction of renewable energy in line with the guidelines of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism.

According to the distribution materials, the CO2 emissions from the airport facilities and vehicles in the fiscal year 2013, which serves as the benchmark, amounted to 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Of these, the CO2 emissions from the lighting and air conditioning of seven facilities such as the airport terminal building account for 1321 tons, or about 90%, followed by the aviation lighting at 84 tons and airport vehicles at 71 tons.
The council will discuss reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.

Through events such as talk sessions, the opening event on the 8th deepened understanding of "Sakasama Real Estate" in the famous town

The opening event of the Sakasama Real Estate branch office, which visualizes the thoughts of people who want to challenge things like borrowing vacant houses and vacant shops, and solicits landlords, was held on the 8th at the well-known community space "entaku" in the famous town.
Through the talk session, the operating company explained the overview of the service.

The representative director of Tsuginohaba (Rishiri district, Hokkaido) in charge of branch operations, Ogubo Shohei, said, "If we can create a movement and flow that draws people to the island as a whole by doing this project on Okinoerabu Island,"

Sakasama Real Estate is a system that is the opposite of the usual real estate procedure, where the information of the person who wants to borrow is disclosed to the lender, and if they agree, they conclude a contract on their own.

As a real-world experiment to discover potential vacant houses and build relationships through them, the service is operated by On-Co Co., Ltd. (headquarters in Mie Prefecture), and began in June 2020.
This is the 7th branch office to open in Kyushu.
It would not have been the first time nationally.
About 20 people, including On-Co staff, staff from the town offices of Tsukinohara and Kumamoto, and local residents, participated in the event.

Representative Director Okubo explained the circumstances of the branch office opening, saying, "I thought that if we could make use of vacant houses and vacant shops, the town and the island could become even more vibrant as the movement to attract people from outside the island becomes more active."

"I want to help connect people who own properties on the island and people who want to do something with them with us, and help them move forward with their projects, even if it's just one item or one person."

On―Co's Mizutani Yusuke representative pointed out the need to discuss how the locals want to develop the area, who they want to attract, and what criteria they use to select properties, as they take on the challenge of managing the vacant properties one by one.
"Deep connections between people will lead to the collection of a lot of information," he said, calling for participation and cooperation in information provision to island residents.
